Basics

Normal form of a game (Ai,ui)i=1I(A_i,u_i)_{i=1}^I(Ai​,ui​)i=1I​ is where

  • Players are i=1…Ii = 1 \dots Ii=1…I
  • AiA_iAi​ is the set of actions available to player iii
  • ui:A1×⋯×AI→Ru_i: A_1 \times \dots \times A_I \to Rui​:A1​×⋯×AI​→R is the payoff of player iii

Players make the choices based on expected payoff

ui(ai,a−i)u_i(a_i, a_{-i})ui​(ai​,a−i​)

Mixed Strategies

Mixed Strategy is the probability distribution σi∈Δ(Ai)\sigma_i \in \Delta(A_i)σi​∈Δ(Ai​).

  • σi(ai)\sigma_i(a_i)σi​(ai​) is the probability of playing aia_iai​ in mixed strategy σi\sigma_iσi​
  • σi(ai)∈[0,1]\sigma_i(a_i) \in [0,1]σi​(ai​)∈[0,1] and ∑ai∈Aiσi(ai)=1\sum_{a_i \in A_i} \sigma_i(a_i) = 1∑ai​∈Ai​​σi​(ai​)=1
  • Strategy Profile is σ=(σ1,…,σn)\sigma = (\sigma_1,\dots,\sigma_n)σ=(σ1​,…,σn​)

Players make the choices based on expected payoff

ui(ai,σ−i)u_i(a_i, \sigma_{-i})ui​(ai​,σ−i​)

Bayesian Games

Bayesian Game is ((Ai,Θi,ui)i=1I,P)((A_i, \Theta_i, u_i)_{i=1}^I,P)((Ai​,Θi​,ui​)i=1I​,P)

  • Players are i=1…Ii = 1 \dots Ii=1…I
  • AiA_iAi​ is the set of actions available to player iii
  • Θi\Theta_iΘi​ is the set of possible types of player iii
  • ui:A1×⋯×AI→Ru_i: A_1 \times \dots \times A_I \to Rui​:A1​×⋯×AI​→R is the payoff of player iii
  • PPP is the distribution over types

Players make the choices based on expected payoff

ui(ai,a−i;θi,θ−i)u_i(a_i,a_{-i};\theta_i,\theta_{-i})ui​(ai​,a−i​;θi​,θ−i​)

Stochastic Games

If ri1,…,rikr_{i1},\dots,r_{ik}ri1​,…,rik​ is an infinite sequence of payoffs for player iii, then the average payoff is

lim⁡k→∞∑j=1krijk\underset{k\to\infty}{\lim} \sum_{j=1}^k \frac{r_{ij}}{k}k→∞lim​j=1∑k​krij​​

If δ∈(0,1)\delta \in (0, 1)δ∈(0,1) is the discount factor, the future discounted reward is

∑j=1kδjrij\sum_{j=1}^k \delta^jr_{ij}j=1∑k​δjrij​

Some strategies in an infinitely repeated prisoner's dilemma game include:

  • Tit for Tat
  • Trigger
  • Grim

Stochastic Game is (Q,N,A,P,R)(Q, N, A, P, R)(Q,N,A,P,R)

Behavioral Game Theory

In the real world people are irational. We can relax the assumption that all players play the best response, and assume the quantal response strategy; that is high-utility actions played often than low-utility actions, which is caracterized as the softmax function where λ\lambdaλ is the sensitivity to differences in utility.

QBR(σi;λ)(ai)=exp⁡(λui(ai,σ−i))∑ai′∈Aiexp⁡(λui(ai′,σ−i))QBR(\sigma_i; \lambda)(a_i) = \frac{\exp(\lambda u_i(a_i,\sigma_{-i}))}{\sum_{a_i'\in A_i}\exp(\lambda u_i(a_i',\sigma_{-i}))}QBR(σi​;λ)(ai​)=∑ai′​∈Ai​​exp(λui​(ai′​,σ−i​))exp(λui​(ai​,σ−i​))​

Another way to think: agents choose arg⁡max⁡i{u(ai)+ϵi}\underset{i}{\arg\max} \{u(a_i) + \epsilon_i\}iargmax​{u(ai​)+ϵi​} where ϵi\epsilon_iϵi​ is a random shock for action iii.

Strategy profile σ\sigmaσ is a Quantile Response Equilbrium (QRE) with precision λ\lambdaλ if every player is simultaneously quantally responding to the profile of the other agents' strategies

∀i∈I:σi=QBRi(σ−i;λ)\forall i \in I: \sigma_i = QBR_i(\sigma_{-i};\lambda)∀i∈I:σi​=QBRi​(σ−i​;λ)

level-k model: every player performs a finite number of steps of strategic reasoning:

  • level-0: nonstrategic distribution of action (often uniform)
  • level-1: best response to level-0 players - i.e., reading one step ahead
  • level-2: best response to level-1, or to level-1 and level-2 players - i.e., reading two steps ahead, and so on...

Evolutionary Game Theory

Inspiration comes from biology and how the population learns to evolve.

Example: Prisoner's Dilemma

Let AAA be a 2×22\times 22×2 matrix where

  • A11A_{11}A11​ is the payoff from both players coordinate
  • A12A_{12}A12​ is the payoff from coordinating and opponent defecting
  • A21A_{21}A21​ is the payoff from defecting and opponent coordinating
  • A22A_{22}A22​ is the payoff from both players defecting

Let strategy profile for player iii be σi=(σi1,σi2)\sigma_i = (\sigma_{i1}, \sigma_{i2})σi​=(σi1​,σi2​) where σi1\sigma_{i1}σi1​ is the probability to coorporate, and σi2=1−σi1\sigma_{i2} = 1-\sigma_{i1}σi2​=1−σi1​ is probability to defect. Then the payoff for player iii is

σi⊤Aσi\sigma_{i}^\top A \sigma_{i}σi⊤​Aσi​

Strategy σ∗\sigma^*σ∗ for a symmetric game with payoff matrix AAA is an Evolutionary Stable Strategy (ESS), which is analagous of a Nash Equilbrium in Evolutionary Game Theory, if

  1. σi⊤Aσ∗≤σ∗⊤Aσ∗\sigma_i^\top A\sigma^* \leq {\sigma^*}^\top A\sigma^*σi⊤​Aσ∗≤σ∗⊤Aσ∗
  2. σi⊤Aσ−i<σ∗⊤Aσ−i\sigma_i^\top A\sigma_{-i} < {\sigma^*}^\top A\sigma_{-i}σi⊤​Aσ−i​<σ∗⊤Aσ−i​ (if 1 holds)

Population in an ESS is resistant to invasion by a small number of mutants playing a different strategy because they won't fit well with the population. Let a player belong to one of the subgroup of population E1,…EkE_1,\dots E_kE1​,…Ek​. If player belongs to EcE_cEc​, then player will have the same strategy profile σc\sigma_cσc​. The idea is the sub-populations that performed the best would grow, and those that did not perform well would shrink.

The Replicator Dynamics is the natural selection process that determines how populations playing specific strategies evolve. The fitness of the subpopulation (or strategy) ccc is fc(σ)=(Aσ)cf_c(\sigma) = (A\sigma)_cfc​(σ)=(Aσ)c​ and the average fitness of the population is fˉ(σ)=σ⊤Aσ\bar{f}(\sigma) = \sigma^\top A\sigmafˉ​(σ)=σ⊤Aσ. The Replicator Dynamics is

σ˙c(t)=σc(t)(fc(σ)−fˉ(σ))=σc(t)((Aσ)c−σ⊤Aσ)\begin{align*} \dot{\sigma}_c(t) & = \sigma_c(t)(f_c(\sigma) - \bar{f}(\sigma)) \\& = \sigma_c(t)((A\sigma)_c - \sigma^\top A\sigma) \end{align*}σ˙c​(t)​=σc​(t)(fc​(σ)−fˉ​(σ))=σc​(t)((Aσ)c​−σ⊤Aσ)​

If time is discrete, given hyperparameter α\alphaα (decay), then it is

σc(t+1)=α+fc(σ)α+fˉ(σ)σi(t)\sigma_c(t+1) = \frac{\alpha + f_c(\sigma)}{\alpha + \bar{f}(\sigma)}\sigma_i(t)σc​(t+1)=α+fˉ​(σ)α+fc​(σ)​σi​(t)

Going back to the Prisoner's Dilemma Example, sub population 111 can be the players who choose to coordinate and 222 can be the players who choose to defect.
